timeline.bodyText:
I've experimented with pushing the Flowable<Loadable<>> down in the stack like this in the past, and while it simplifies usage, it also complicates the semantics of the internal API; these methods no longer simply do work and then either complete or return an error, but rather they stream status. This is slightly harder for clients of these methods to understand, and is really only introduced here because of how the UI streams emit state. It also is questionable whether this simplifies the code, since the transformation to a Flowable still has to happen somewhere.
Can we wrap the state higher up in the stack instead, as close to the subscription as possible?
Also note that Loadable is modeled around the action of something being loaded from the database, not creating, updating, and deleting.

timeline.bodyText:
This method is actually doing a lot more than just converting the Completable to a Single; it's returning whether the Single completed successfully, and is causing a side effect on the provided Consumer. I'd suggest a few improvements to make this clearer:

Give the method a more explicit name, like toBooleanSingle() to indicate this is doing something special.
Call the callback param for when it's actually invoked (onError).
If this is every called with null exceptionConsumer (I didn't see it on a quick scan), create a separate override of this method without the Consumer (i.e. toBooleanSingle(Completable) and toBooleanSingle(Completable, onErro).
Add minimal Javadoc explaining these semantics (esp. since the method is public.

timeline.bodyText: I would avoid showing the specific exception message to the user, since a) we don't have control over what is show, and b) we'll probably need to whole stack track to diagnose the problem anyway. Also, better to have a fixed message that can be translated if necessary.
